repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Second Bank Restructuring and
            Debt Management Program Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. The two loans by the Bank
            supporting the bank restructuring and debt management
            program (BRDP) present an interesting, though complex, set
            of lessons: these lessons span the spectrum from the
            positive - where client commitment, choice of appropriate
            lending instrument, and close collaboration among the
            international financial institutions (IFIs), led to positive
            outcomes - to the more circumspect, that often Bank
            operations face, with country risks that are easier to
            identify than to mitigate within the context of sector
            adjustment loans. 1) Importance of client commitment to
            reform: The excellent Government's cooperation with the
            Bank allowed the genuine commitment of the Bank team to work
            in identifying feasible policy options for dealing with the
            aftermath of the financial crisis. This joint effort led to
            a satisfactory implementation experience, despite major
            risks, in particular given that the cost of not supporting
            the Government's reform efforts, was deemed
            unacceptably high. 2) Importance of selecting an appropriate
            lending instrument: experience clearly vindicated the choice
            of two single-tranche programmatic loans, over a more
            traditional single-loan two-tranche approach, an approach
            that also provided the Bank with leverage to work with the
            Government, reaching satisfactory resolutions of some
            outstanding issues from the first loan. This choice also
            enabled lessons from past Bank experience with Jamaica: the
            Bank reduced the risk of delay, and failure in the
            achievement of the program's medium term aims, by
            avoiding locking the client early on into an overly
            ambitious, politically sensitive, and risky agenda with
            excessive conditionality. 3) Importance of close
            collaboration with other IFIs and with the country staff:
            especially in the dysfunctional phasing of the reforms
            programs, where risks were clearly high, the Bank gained
            from the sectoral perspectives of the Inter-American
            Development Bank, and the macro views of the International
            Monetary Fund, while in turn both these institutions
            benefited from the Bank's knowledge in restructuring of
            banking sectors, as well as its often more conservative
            views on evolution of macroeconomic variables. Further
            lessons address issues on designing adjustment programs,
            and, on the major risks facing the sustainability of reforms.

repnme.cdata!:
Jamaica - Second Bank Restructuring and
            Debt Management Program Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will support the second
            phase of the Government's Bank Restructuring and Debt
            Management Program, which includes the resolution of
            financial institutions; phase-out of the crisis management
            agency Financial Sector Adjustment Company Limited (FINSAC);
            restructuring, and management of the public debt arising
            from the resolution of the financial crisis; regulatory, and
            supervisory reforms in the financial sector; and, improving
            the financial infrastructure for renewed bank lending. The
            project will contribute to moving the resolution of the
            financial crisis toward completion, by supporting the
            disposal of majority equity stakes in the last two
            remaining, major government financial institutions to
            foreign investors; and, will enable the Government to
            continue its efforts at servicing the liabilities generated
            during the crisis in cash. Moreover, it will support the
            strengthening of regulatory, and supervisory framework for
            the financial sector in the country, including support the
            debt management program by lengthening the maturities of the
            pubic debt, and replacement of stock, of relatively
            expensive, shorter-term, domestic debt with relatively
            cheaper international debt (assuming only modest
            depreciation of the Jamaican currency). While risks exist,
            i.e., exogenous economic shocks, actions taken by the
            Government have changed the nature of risks, and contributed
            to increase confidence in risk management.
